raw_comment:
Notice: I notice that legacy applicants have a greater chance of getting admitted to an elite college no matter the parents’ income. I also notice that there is a significant spike in both legacy and non-legacy applicants in the 99.9 parents’ income rank. I also notice that the difference between legacy and non-legacy applicants isn’t super significant until around the 70th rank of parents’ income. 
Wonder: I wonder why the gap between legacy and non-legacy applicants isn’t significant until after the 70th rank for parents’ income? I also wonder why the admissions rate for non-legacy applicants dips below the average admissions rate between the 70th and 90th ranks for parents’ income? I wonder why the spike is so much higher for legacy applicants than non-legacy applicants after the 90th rank for parents’ income? I wonder what test score is being examined for this graph?
Relate to You: This is applicable to me as the admissions advantage is present in all colleges, not just elite colleges. In order to get into college, I had to submit essays and complete applications regarding my parents’ education and financial status. Although I didn’t think about it at the time, I am sure that this information was probably part of the process of determining whether I would be admitted or not. 
Headline: Parent Privilege at Elite Colleges
ace_sentences: Legacy applicants have a greater chance of admission to an elite college than non-legacy applicants.
This advantage exists for legacy applicants at every parents' income level.
There is a significant spike in the number of legacy applicants at the 99.9 parents' income rank.
There is a significant spike in the number of non-legacy applicants at the 99.9 parents' income rank.
The difference between legacy applicants and non-legacy applicants is not significant until around the 70th parents' income rank.
I wonder why the gap between legacy applicants and non-legacy applicants is not significant until after the 70th parents' income rank.
I wonder why the admission rate for non-legacy applicants is below the average admission rate between the 70th and 90th parents' income ranks.
I wonder why the spike is much higher for legacy applicants than for non-legacy applicants after the 90th parents' income rank.
I wonder which test score the graph examines.
The admissions advantage is present in all colleges.
The admissions advantage is not limited to elite colleges.
This situation is applicable to me.
In order to get into college, I submitted essays.
In order to get into college, I completed applications.
The applications asked about my parents' education.
The applications asked about my parents' financial status.
At that time, I did not think about this information.
I am sure that this information was part of the admission process.
This information probably influenced whether I was admitted.
The headline is: Parent Privilege at Elite Colleges.
